title: 103_s1208
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Independence Hall Commemorative Coin Act". The Congress finds that historic buildings in Philadelphia, including Congress Hall and Independence Hall, were cared for by local government units before the National Park Service took over preservation duties. The Federal Government, through the National Park Service, now maintains historic sites like Congress Hall and Independence Hall in Philadelphia. Financial constraints have hindered the government from meeting the capital needs of these sites, prompting the proposal to mint a commemorative coin to fund their preservation. The proposal suggests minting a commemorative coin to fund the preservation of historic sites like Congress Hall and Independence Hall in Philadelphia. The Secretary of the Treasury will issue up to 1,000,000 $1 silver coins with a specific weight, diameter, and composition. The design of the coins will feature the Liberty Bell and Independence Hall, along with various inscriptions. These coins will be legal tender as per the United States Code. The Secretary will obtain silver for the coins from stockpiles under the Strategic and Critical Materials Stock Piling Act. The design will be chosen after consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The design for the coins authorized by this Act will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and reviewed by the Citizens Commemorative Coin Advisory Committee. The coins may be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a designated Mint facility for a period of up to one year after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 7. SALE OF THE COINS.

(a) Sale Price.--Coins sold at face value plus surcharge and costs.
(b) Bulk Sales.--Discounts for bulk purchases.
(c) Prepaid Orders.--Accepted with discounts.
(d) Surcharge Required.--$7 per coin.

SEC. 8. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. SEC. 8. GENERAL WAIVER OF PROCUREMENT REGULATIONS. No procurement laws apply to goods/services for this Act. Compliance with equal employment laws still required. SEC. 9. DISTRIBUTION OF SURCHARGES. 50% of surcharges from coin sales go to the Treasury to reduce national debt, and 50% goes to the Independence Hall Preservation Fund for park improvements. SEC. 10. AUDITS. SEC. 10. The Comptroller General can audit the Independence Hall Preservation Fund's expenditure. SEC. 11. Coins issued are subject to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 12. Financial assurances required. SEC. 11. The coins issued under this Act are subject to the provisions of section 5134 of title 31, United States Code, relating to the Numismatic Public Enterprise Fund. SEC. 12. Financial assurances ensure no net cost to the Government and require adequate security for payment.
